replies.msg:
BCIT means BC Institute of Technology. It's mostly training for practical real life jobs and skip the philosophy, liberal arts training needed in University.

So there are some grads that finish university and then go for two year training in BCIT.

For example, you can go to University to get Computer Science degree and then go to BCIT to get Cisco /Microsoft professional designation.

You can also go to BCIT to take training on trades - electrician, mechanic... Work that require lots of hand, blue collar and high paying.

replies.msg:
Early childhood education? Or you are elementary school teacher?

Both have professional license here in my province of BC. You need to submit your education and training history to BC government for evaluation. Then they will be able to tell you what courses you are missing.

After knowing which courses are missing, you will go to university to compete those courses to become certified.

Early childhood education is 2 years not four years. Elementary school teachers requires a degree first and then 2 additional years.

But your case, you will get some equivalent standing so you can expect maybe half the courses needed than normal students

quote.msg:
Misleading statement.

Citizenship comes with rights æ¬Šåˆ© not benifits. So you can vote, you can run for office, you can work.. Etc

When you move to my province of BC with Canadian passport, you establish residency upon arrival.

I remeber at form 5, I returned to a Canada. The border agent asked how long I was gone... And I said since elementary school. She said "Welcome home!" (very sweet memory)

Immidately, your children can enroll in free public school for free. I arrived in the summer and I attended public school grade 11 immediately in September and it was free - no tuition.

You do not get welfare ç¶œæ´ unless you have stable place to live and you are poor. There is affordable housing ( å…¬å±‹) but there is a lineup so you can apply but have to wait until availability.

What you don't get is Canada pension plan åœ‹å®¶ç´šé•·ç³§, until you start working and paying into it. You also don't get Old Age Security ( é•·è€…ç”Ÿæœé‡‘) until you lived in Canada for 10 years.

replies.msg:
western welfare systems are rosy to others

i just met an old man living in a public housing unit in hk by himself even he has a green card because he couldnt afford healthcare in the States

Hong Kongs welfare to be upfront is not bad at all it all boils down to the augmenting aging issue.

However I would always choose western countries over hong kong at any given time.

Probably BCIT is the place to go.

You can take It courses for Network+, Microsoft certs or Cisco certs. That is a 2 year diploma.

Alternatively BCIT can also give you diploma in electrician, or mecahnic or other Trades that uses hands a lot.

Post-grad work permit normally is 1 year or 2 years. If your degree is 4 years university, you get two year work permit. If it's a 2 year college diploma, work permit is 1 year.

I am still awaiting Canada's Hong Kong rescue policy for 18-35 and maybe the conditions would be more favorable.

replies.msg:
If the Canada's Hong Kong rescue policy is aiming 18-35 year old, and providing student loans to Hong Kongers then we can make an educated guess.
1) it aims at youth and young adults and doesn't matter if there is a degree because Canada student loans is for getting a degrre
2) if it's government student loans to go to school, then it is reasonable to guess Hong Kongers are paying domestic rates like normal Canadians (that is about 33% of the cost of international students).
3) if it about Hong Kongers and attracting talent, then it's not important if they hold a BNO or not. What would be important is they hold core values of democracy, gender equality and human rights.
4) Canadians government will be silly if we exclude BNO holders because we are competing against UK, Australia, and USA in attracting high quality immigrants (and their youth and money) into the country. We don't just surrender all best talent ( the 23-35 year olds) to other nations.

You already have Cico cert and a degree (in computer science? ).

Then you should be golden and in high demand and have no problem finding IT job in major Canadian cities especially if you are willing to go to rural area (just to get permanent residency) . Just get a working holiday and work for a company and ask them to change to Work Permit and then after staying for 2 years (1 year as work holiday, one year as work apply for immigration.

But if you want to do BCIT for the one year work permit... You can do something fun like the Microsoft's MCSA (easiest one). Most effort should be made to improve talking/conversation English while you are here.

Alternatively, you can wait for the Canadian Hong Kong rescue plan to see if path gets easier.

replies.msg:
You can apply for working holiday and come to Canada. Then find a job.

The Canadian company find it a complex task to hire someone overseas because the need to apply for work permit. I tried getting a Japanese translator a work visa and it would have taken months.

It's a lot easier to spend the time and effort if you are already working (by working holiday) there and they like you. They can spend months doing the paper work while you are already working there. Because they will either spend the time applying yoh a work permit or spending time going through resume and interviewing new candidates.

Company may also put the effort to apply for work permit if you are seriously good.

Alternatively, maybe wait for the rescue package to decide.

replies.msg:
The hard way is to... Apply for Canadian jobs from Hong Kong and hope they hire you.

Many companies including start-ups don't have the staff to go through all thr government process. And it takes months. Even if they are willing to wait 3 months, what happens if you went for another job in Hong Kong?

So as I said.. Safe way is work holiday. Arrive in Canada already allowed to work anywhere. Work in the IT company and perform pretty good and then they can apply for work visa.

Without rescue package, another way is to finish university here in Canada and get the two year work permit. You find work and then apply for permanent residency directly. Computer science Canadian degree, 1 + year Canada work experience in specialize field (like IT) and good English and such should push your immigration score to 460/470. Besides, you might find true love with a white Canadian or Asian-Canadian and immigrate through marriage.

replies.msg:
Misleading statement.

Canada is not dark side of the moon with no sunlight in the winter.

Yellowknife is one of the most North cities we have in the North Pole. You can see Northern lights åŒ—æ¥µå…‰ in the winter. Extremely popular among Japanese tourists.

During December, Yellowknife sunrise at 9:45 and sunset at 3:10pm. So you get 6hrs of sunlight a day. During July, sunrise is 5:00am and sunset at 11:30pm - over 18 hrs of sunlight.

https://www.timeanddate.com/sun/canada/yellowknife?month=12

Vancouver is the at southmost area in Canada, touching the border of USA. Summer time, Vancouver sunrise at 5:30am and sunset at around 9:45pm. In December, Vancouver sunrise at 8:10am and sunset around 8:15pm.

So depending on which area between southmost point and north pole, you will get between 6-12 hrs of sun during winter. In the summer, you will get between 16hrs - 18.5hrs of sunlight.

replies.msg:
You missed the point. Seasonal affected disorder is well documented and known to affect public health in northern regions. It's seasonal, months of lack of sunlight does cause mental health degradation for some people, doesn't need to be in the dark for the whole year.
https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/seasonal-affective-disorder/symptoms-causes/syc-20364651

The point is if you work 8-5 job, and sunrise s at 9:30 and set at 4:30, thats practically no sunlight for your weekday life for 2 months. This is 2 hours drive north of 49-parallel US-Canada border, not even that far north.

replies.msg:
Wrong again. Canadian citizens status are entitled to benefits and rights, but with some administrative restrictions. TDSB's requirement of 12 month residency is specific to the school board, not a universal rule.
This is dictated by the province, and sometimes, specific school board Eg. BC requires proof of residency of the parents, but not a certain length. Alberta mandates cost-recovery tuition but not foreign student fees for non-Alberta residents family, also don't require prior residency.
Some province will process and provide healthcare as soon as you set up residency (Alberta, Manitoba) but some requires 3 month max waiting period (Ontario prior to March 2020, Quebec, Sask.) before they will process the application.
This has nothing to do with paying tax or not. One can have low enough income and pay no tax and still entitled to benefits. This is purely administrative.

If u don't mind, it's better if i explain in English
Sure you can always take IELTS until you achieve a reasonable score. However university will also looks at your other academic performance for example ur dse, or your high diploma. I have worked in a university for a while as a Teacher Assistant and a researcher, you might luckily see me if you are going to universities in BC or Toronto but you have to ask the school how they are going to examine your admission, for maybe you high diploma might not be approved or weighs much less than your other academic result such for example DSE

replies.msg:
https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/news/2020/11/measures-to-support-hong-kong-residents-including-youth-to-come-to-canada.html

New temporary and permanent pathways for Hong Kong youth

Canada will expedite the processing of permits for young people from Hong Kong who are eligible and want to come to Canada to work or study. We have already seen an increase in study permit applications in the first half of 2020 compared to 2019, and the government will continue to promote this opportunity.
In addition to the existing work and study options for Hong Kong youth, a new work permit initiative specific to Hong Kong youth will provide open work permits of up to 3 years in duration, with eligibility criteria centred on post-secondary education in Canada or abroad completed in the last 5 years. Eligible spouses or common-law partners, as well as dependent children, can also apply for a study or work permit, as appropriate. This initiative is expected to launch soon.
For those who come here to either study or work, 2 new pathways to permanent residence are being created, which will be available in 2021:
The first will target former Hong Kong residents who have gained a minimum of 1 year of authorized work experience in Canada and meet other criteria such as minimum language and education levels.
The second pathway will be for those who have graduated from a post-secondary institution in Canada. These individuals can then apply directly for permanent residence.
For both these pathways, principal applicants will also be able to include in-Canada spouses, partners, and dependent children in their application.
Canada will benefit from these new measures, which will ensure these former Hong Kong residents have the skills and education to integrate well and contribute to our economy.

pinned.msg:
https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/news/2020/11/measures-to-support-hong-kong-residents-including-youth-to-come-to-canada.html

New temporary and permanent pathways for Hong Kong youth

Canada will expedite the processing of permits for young people from Hong Kong who are eligible and want to come to Canada to work or study. We have already seen an increase in study permit applications in the first half of 2020 compared to 2019, and the government will continue to promote this opportunity.
In addition to the existing work and study options for Hong Kong youth, a new work permit initiative specific to Hong Kong youth will provide open work permits of up to 3 years in duration, with eligibility criteria centred on post-secondary education in Canada or abroad completed in the last 5 years. Eligible spouses or common-law partners, as well as dependent children, can also apply for a study or work permit, as appropriate. This initiative is expected to launch soon.
For those who come here to either study or work, 2 new pathways to permanent residence are being created, which will be available in 2021:
The first will target former Hong Kong residents who have gained a minimum of 1 year of authorized work experience in Canada and meet other criteria such as minimum language and education levels.
The second pathway will be for those who have graduated from a post-secondary institution in Canada. These individuals can then apply directly for permanent residence.
For both these pathways, principal applicants will also be able to include in-Canada spouses, partners, and dependent children in their application.
Canada will benefit from these new measures, which will ensure these former Hong Kong residents have the skills and education to integrate well and contribute to our economy.
